Key Match Events: Quinton de Kock smashed a second successive century
South Africa beat Australia by 134 runs
Quinton de Kock scored his 19th ODI century and third against Australia
Aiden Markram scored a half century (56)
Kagiso Rabada took 3 wickets for 33 runs
Marco Jansen took 2 wickets for 54 runs
Keshav Maharaj took 2 wickets for 30 runs
Australia was dismissed for 177 in 40.5 overs
Pre-Game Insights: Pat Cummins won the toss and decided to field first at the Ekana International Stadium on Thursday
Australia made two changes in their lineup, bringing in Marcus Stoinis for Cameron Green and Josh Inglis for Alex Carey
David Warner's 122 is the highest individual score in Australia and South Africa World Cup games
Australia have never played at the Ekana Stadium in Lucknow. South Africa played here last year and beat India by 9 runs.
Post-Match Reflections: Quinton de Kock speaks on his Player of the Match: 'It was a great win for the boys, to be honest, we didn't know how the pitch would play, we assessed the conditions beautifully and then applied ourselves well with the bat.'

Coach Pat Cummins will be particularly concerned about the performance of his batsmen, who failed to break the 200-run mark as they were caught in a web of spin bowling spun by India's skilled bowlers.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Quinton de Kock hit his 31st half-century in just 51 balls
100 runs up for Proteas in 106 balls (Q de Kock 61, T Bavuma 33)
Maxwell break the opening partnership, sends Proteas' skipper Bavuma (35) to pavilion in the 20th over, as the latter goes for a big shot and get caught David Warner.
After losing skipper Bavuma, South Africa touched the 150-runs mark in 162 balls.
Proteas lose 2nd Wicket: Adam Zampa gives a breakthrough for Australia, as he picks up the wickets of Rassie van der Dussen in the 29th over.
Q de Kock: Century for de Kock in 91 balls. This is his 19th ODI century and third against Australia (100 off 90 balls – 8 x 4, 5 x 6)

Glen Maxwell dismisses Quinton de Kock in the 35th over as the batter limbs into the reverse-pull, the ball pops from a good length, deflects off the back of his bat and down into the stumps to end a mighty innings. He scored 109 in 106 balls.
South Africa are 250-up in 43 overs all thanks to the powerful half century by Markram.
After scoring a half century, Aiden Markram loses his wicket to Pat Cummins in the 44th over. He scored 56 runs in just 44 balls.
Finally the wait is over and 300-runs up for Proteas the 49th over.

Wickets!!! Starc takes two wickets in final over of the game. He dismisses Jansen as it was a straightforward catch to David Warner. Apart from this, David Miller too went back to pavilion as he failed to defend a perfect yorker.
After 50 overs, the Proteas could score 311/7 and gave a target of 312 runs for Kangaroos to chase.
For Australia, Mitchell Starc and Glenn Maxwell took two wickets each, while, Josh Hazlewood, Pat Cummins and Adam Zampa took one each.
Australia slumped to 70-6 before giving up their pursuit of an unlikely victory, hoping to salvage their run-rate instead but were dismissed for 177 with 55 balls to spare.

Australia lost half their wickets for 65 runs and had no answer against Kagiso Rabada (3-33), Marco Jansen (2-54) and Keshav Maharaj (2-30) as they folded for 177 in 40.5 overs with Marnus Labuschagne (46) their only top-order batsman to fire.
